I am using a CANdle to control a LED strip; however, not all the LEDs light up on the strip.  I have tried using other strips, and I’ve had the same issue with all of them.  What should I do?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Use the Rio to talk to it instead of the CANdle?

LED strips have been commonly used by teams for several years for a variety of reasons. They allow teams to debug robot functionality from the audience, provide a visual marker for their robot, and...

Note long strands typically need external supplemental power.  How are you powering the strip?

link_counts.title: Addressable LEDs — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Cole
posts.cooked: We are powering it with the VRM

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: How many LEDs and what are their current draws? 300 x 20 ma = 6 amps… Which is above the max vrm output.  That strip you have looks pretty dense.  5v or 12v?

posts.name: Cole
posts.cooked: Its 5V.  This is the specific strip: https://www.amazon.com/BTF-LIGHTING-WS2812B-Individual-Addressable-Non-waterproof/dp/B01CDTEGGO/ref=sr_1_2?crid=4ORHQQ9SQDZK&keywords=btf%2Blighting%2Bws2812B1m144lw30&qid=1648332190&sprefix=btf%2Blighting%2Bws2812b1m144lw30%2Caps%2C122&sr=8-2&th=1

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
OK.  Well that says 0.3 watts per led.  144 LEDs.  At 5 V.   Power = VI

SO,

0.3 W x 144 = 5 V x I.

I = 8.24 AMPS.

You may have a current problem.

posts.name: Cole
posts.cooked: Since the VRM can only go up to 2 amps and 12V (with also had the same problem) causes the system to overheat, how could I fix that?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
Get a buck converter or a step down converter. 12 volt to 5 volt, and run it from a pdh slot.

Product Features:  This is a Dc 5V(FIXED OUTPUT) 50W waterproof voltage regulator, capable of driving a 10a load Parameters: Input Voltage: 12/24V  Output Voltage: 5V Output Current: 10A(MAX)  Line Regulation: ±0.2% Load...

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked:
We are using the same 12V-5 converter - works great.

Also, do you have the LED count set to the correct number?

posts.name: Cole
posts.cooked: The CTRE library does not specify a count.  I the one that does specify a count also did not work. CTRE_Phoenix: com.ctre.phoenix.led.CANdle Class Reference

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked: I see - just the animation features ask for a LED count

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
If your CANdle isn’t controlling all the LEDs on the strip, I’d look at your code and make sure you specified a large enough LED count.

setLED has an overloaded method that allows you to specify the count:

declaration: package: com.ctre.phoenix.led, class: CANdle

Each of the Animations specify the number of LEDs to apply the animation to:

declaration: package: com.ctre.phoenix.led, class: Animation

ColeH:

We are powering it with the VRM

While that can work, in general we wouldn’t recommend powering the CANdle from the VRM . LEDs draw a lot of power and even the 12V 2A slot on the VRM won’t be able to supply enough current for a large load. The CANdle has a 5V regulator on-board, which allows it to supply 6A at 5V. Since the input range is from 6 to 28, you can power it off a 10A breaker from your power distribution board.

But, you may run into current problems even with the CANdle’s regulator, as Tom Line pointed out an expected current consumption of 8.24 amps. You may want to power the LEDs externally or use the brightness config to reduce the brightness and the overall current consumption of the LEDs.

Peter_Johnson:

Use the Rio to talk to it instead of the CANdle?

This can also work, and if supply current isn’t an issue, you can use the CANdle as a regulator and passthrough. Power the CANdle with supply voltage and pass the signal pulse train through the CAN leads. In your case you’d use the RIO to generate the pulse train instead of the Arduino, though.
